When a small group of living beings (a small population) is separated from the main population, from which it originates (e.g. when they cross a mountain range or a river, or when they settle on a new island, so that they cannot easily return), they often find themselves in a different environment than before.

This new environment has different resources and different competitors, so that the new population needs different characteristics or adaptations to be a strong competitor, rather than what it needed before.
The original population has not changed at all. It still needs the same adaptations as before.
Over time, the new population adapts to its new environment, and then it looks less and less like the other population.
After thousands or even millions of years two populations may look so different that they can no longer be assigned to the same species.
We call this process speciation, which simply means the emergence of new species. Speciation is an unavoidable consequence and a very important part of evolution.

Technological determinism is a term that encompasses a wide range of ideas in practice, from the technological push or the technological imperative to the strict sense that human destiny is determined by a logic that is linked to scientific laws and its manifestation in technology.

Most interpretations of technological determinism share two general views. One, that the development of technology follows a path which is largely beyond cultural or political influence, and two, that technology has effects on societies which are more inherent than socially determined.
One could say that the automobile is unavoidably linked to the development of roads.
However, a nationwide road network for only a small number of cars is not economically viable. Therefore, new production methods are being developed to reduce the cost of car ownership.

The widespread ownership of automobiles also leads to an increase in the number of accidents on the roads, which in turn leads to the invention of new techniques in the medical field to repair damaged bodies.

The use of ships for the transport of goods is by far the most efficient way to transport large numbers of people and goods across the oceans.

One of the most recent examples of this is the North Atlantic Campaign in World War II. The Americans tried to transport personnel and supplies across the Atlantic Ocean to help Britain.

Ancient cultures and peoples began to keep them as pets to get easily at their milk, fur, meat and skin.

After his farewell by the Congress on 4 July, a handwritten, signed by the Congress President John Hancock and the Secretary Charles Thomson, was sent to the printing house of John Dunlap a few blocks away.
During the night, between 150 and 200 copies were made, which are now known as the "Dunlap broadsides".
The first public reading of the document was given by John Nixon in the Independence Hall courtyard on July 8.
One was sent to George Washington on July 6, which he read to his troops in New York on July 9. A copy reached London on August 10.
Of the 25 Dunlap broadsides that still exist, they are the oldest surviving copies of the document. The original manuscript has not survived the ages.

Hershey and Chase used phages or viruses to insert their own DNA into a bacterium.
They took two experiments, in which they either marked the DNA of the phage with radioactive phosphorus or marked a protein in the phage with radioactive sulfur.

Traffic flow is the study of the movement of individual drivers and vehicles between two points and the interactions that take place between them.
Unfortunately, it is difficult to study traffic flows, as drivers' behavior cannot be predicted with 100 percent certainty.
Fortunately, drivers tend to behave consistently; therefore, traffic flows have a certain constancy and can be roughly represented mathematically.

These relationships help with the planning, design and operation of facilities at the roadside.

The Amazon is also the widest river in the world, in some places up to six miles wide.

Content theories focus on finding what moves or appeals to people.
These theories suggest that people have certain needs and/or desires that are internalized as they mature.
These theories are concerned with what makes certain people want to do exactly what they do and what influences in their environment cause them to do certain things or not to do certain things.
Two popular content theories are Maslow's hierarchy of needs and Herzberg's two-factor theory.

This type of manager has problems making unpopular decisions, enforcing disciplinary measures, assessing performance, assigning responsibilities and taking on employees.
At the other end of the spectrum, one becomes an unrecognizable individual who does everything differently than the team did and takes everything for themselves.
In the end, the team manager is responsible for the success and failure of the team.
This behavior often leads to conflicts between the leaders and the rest of the team.
Virtual teams are led to the same standards of excellence as conventional teams, but there are subtle differences.

They often have more autonomy than traditional team members because their teams meet in different time zones that may not be considered by the local management.
The presence of a real "invisible team" (Larson and LaFasto 1989, p. 109) is also a unique component of a virtual team.

KI (Künstliche Intelligenz) is often associated with science fiction, but is a key branch of computer science that deals with behaviour, learning and the adaptation of machines to intelligent behaviour.
Research in the field of AI includes the construction of machines to automate tasks that require intelligent behaviour.
Examples of this are controlling, setting up strategies and timetables, the ability to answer customer questions, and handwriting, voice and face recognition.
Such things have become independent disciplines that focus on finding solutions to real life problems.
The KI system is now widely used in the fields of business, medicine, engineering and the military and has been incorporated into numerous software applications for home computers and video games.
Excursions are an important part of every school class. Not infrequently a teacher would like to take her pupils to places which cannot be reached by bus.
Virtual excursions are a technical solution. Students can view museum exhibits from their classroom, visit an aquarium or admire beautiful works of art.
Sharing a virtual excursion is also a great way to reflect on a trip and share experiences with future classes.

For example, students at the Bennet School in North Carolina design a website every year about their trip to the state capital. The website is redesigned every year, but the previous versions remain online and serve as a scrapbook.

Blogs can also help to improve the writing skills of students. Although students at the beginning of their blogging experience often have a sloppy grammar and spelling, this usually changes when there is an audience.
Students are often a very critical audience, so the blog author makes an effort to improve his writing style to avoid criticism.
Blogging "forces the students to learn more about the world around them." The need to attract the interest of the audience inspires the students to write cleverly and interestingly (Toto, 2004).
Blogging is a tool that inspires collaboration and encourages students to continue learning outside the traditional school day.

The appropriate use of blogs can enable students to become more analytical and critical; by reacting to Internet materials, students can define their positions in the context of the texts of others and express their own perspectives on certain topics. (Oravec, 2002)
Ottawa is Canada's enchanting, bilingual capital and is distinguished by a series of art galleries and museums that present Canada's past and present.

The present-day Casablanca was founded by Berber fishermen in the 10th century BC and was used by the Phoenicians, the Romans and the Merinids as a strategic port with the name Anfa.
The Portuguese destroyed them and rebuilt them under the name Casa Branca only to abandon them after an earthquake in 1755.
The Moroccan Sultan rebuilt the city as Dar el Beida and it was given the name Casablanca by Spanish merchants who set up trading posts there.
Casablanca is one of the most uninteresting places to shop in all of Morocco.

Goma is a tourist town in the Democratic Republic of the Congo in the extreme east near Rwanda.
In 2002, Goma was destroyed by the lava of the Nyiragongo volcano, which buried most of the city's streets, particularly the city centre.
While Goma is relatively safe, every stay outside Goma should be carefully planned to keep abreast of the ongoing fighting in the North Kivu province.
The city is also the starting point for the ascent of the volcano Nyiragongo and for some of the cheapest gorilla tracking tours in Africa.
You can use bodabodas (motorcycle taxis) to get around Goma. The usual (local) fare is about 500 Congolese francs for the short ride.

The Kruger National Park (KNP) is located in the northeast of South Africa. It borders on Mozambique in the east, Zimbabwe in the north and the Crocodile River in the south.
The park has an area of 19,500 km2 and is divided into 14 different ecosystems, each of which supports a different animal population.
It is one of the main attractions of South Africa and is considered the flagship of the South African National Parks (SANParks).
Like all South African national parks, the park charges daily conservation and entrance fees.
It may also be worthwhile to purchase a Wild Card which grants access either to selected parks in South Africa or to all South African national parks.
Hong Kong Island is the namesake of the territory of Hong Kong and is the center of attraction for many tourists.
The buildings that make up Hong Kong's skyline were compared to a shimmering diagram of a balcony, visible because of the presence of the waters of Victoria Harbour.
For the best views of Hong Kong, you should leave the island and take the ferry to the opposite shore of Kowloon.
The majority of Hong Kong Island's urban development is concentrated along the northern coastline, which was reclaimed from the sea.
This is the place where the British colonists took over. If you are looking for traces of the colonial past of the region, this is a good starting point.
The Sundarbans are the largest mangrove forest in the world and extend 80 km from the Bangladeshi and Indian hinterland to the coast.
The Sundarbans were declared a UNESCO World Heritage Site in 1997. The part of the forest within the Indian state is called Sundarbans National Park.
The forests are not only mangrove swamps – they also include some of the last remaining stands of the mighty jungle that once covered the Ganges plain.
The Sundarbans cover an area of 3850 km2, of which a third is covered by water and marshes.
The Sundarbans are a nature reserve since 1966, and according to estimates there are now 400 Bengal tigers and about 30,000 spotted deer living there.

The Oyapock River Bridge is a cable-stayed bridge. It spans the Oyapock River and connects the cities of Oiapoque in Brazil and Saint-Georges de l'Oyapock in French Guiana.
Their two towers are 83 metres high, their length is 378 metres and they have two lanes with a width of 3.50 metres.
The clearance height under the bridge is 15 m. The construction work was completed in August 2011, but the opening to traffic was not until March 2017.
The bridge is expected to be fully operational in September 2017. It is hoped that the Brazilian customs posts will then be completed.
The Guaraní were the most important indigenous group that inhabited present-day eastern Paraguay. They lived as semi-nomadic hunter-gatherers who also practised subsistence agriculture.
The Chaco region was also the home of other groups of indigenous tribes, such as the Guaycurú and the Payaguá, who survived by hunting, gathering and fishing.
Paraguay, formerly known as the Great Province of the West Indies, was created in the 16th century as a result of the meeting of the Spanish conquerors with the indigenous groups.
The Spaniards began the colonisation period, which lasted three centuries.
Since the founding of Asuncion in 1537, Paraguay has managed to preserve much of its indigenous character and identity.
Argentina is known for having the best polo team and players in the world.
The biggest tournament of the year takes place in December on Las Cañitas polo fields.
Smaller tournaments and competitions can also be viewed at other times of the year.
Information about tournaments and sales outlets for polo tickets can be found at the Asociacion Argentina de Polo.
The official currency of the Falkland Islands is the Falkland Pound (FKP), which is pegged to the value of the British Pound (GBP).
Money can be exchanged at the only bank on the island, which is located across from the FIC West Store in Stanley.
The British pound is generally accepted everywhere on the islands and at Stanley Credit Cards. US dollars are often accepted.
Credit cards are unlikely to be accepted on remote islands, but British and US currency may be accepted; check with the owners in advance to find out what payment methods are accepted.
It is almost impossible to exchange the currency of the Falkland Islands outside the islands themselves, so you should exchange your money before leaving the islands.
Because Montevideo is south of the equator, it is summer there when it is winter in the northern hemisphere and vice versa.

Winter can be deceptively cool: The temperatures rarely go below freezing, but wind and humidity make it feel colder than the thermometer indicates.
There are no pronounced rainy or dry seasons: The rainfall remains more or less the same throughout the year.
